title: 103_hr2632
content: SECTION 1. SHORT TITLE. The "Patent and Trademark Office Authorization Act of 1993" authorizes $103,000,000 for the Patent and Trademark Office for salaries and expenses in fiscal year 1994. This funding is derived from the Patent and Trademark Office Fee Surcharge Fund. The Reconciliation Act of 1990 authorizes fees to be made available to the Patent and Trademark Office for fiscal year 1994, based on the amount collected from fees under title 35, United States Code, and the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 3. Amounts appropriated under this Act may remain available until expended. SEC. 4. The fee for filing a trademark registration application shall be $245, effective upon enactment, with any fee adjustments not effective before October 1, 1994. SEC. 5. Interim patent extensions. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to include provisions for extending the regulatory review period for patents under certain circumstances. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, allows for an interim extension of a patent's regulatory review period if it extends beyond the patent's expiration. The application for extension must include details of the product under review, the relevant federal statute, and the patent information. The application for interim patent extension must include details of the patent, claims related to the product under review, information for determining eligibility, a description of applicant activities during the regulatory review period, and any additional information required by the Commissioner. The Commissioner may require patent or other information for the product under review. If the patent is eligible for an extension, a notice will be published, and an interim extension certificate may be issued for up to 1 year. The Commissioner may issue a certificate of interim extension for a patent for up to 1 year. The owner of the patent can apply for up to 4 subsequent interim extensions, with exceptions for certain cases. Each application must be made within a specific timeframe before the expiration of the previous extension. Each certificate of interim extension for a patent can be granted for up to 1 year and must be recorded in the patent file. The extension terminates 60 days after the product receives commercial marketing permission, unless the applicant notifies the Commissioner and provides additional information within that period. The patent can be further extended for up to 5 years from the original expiration date or upon commercial marketing approval. Rights during the extension period are limited to uses under regulatory review. During the interim extension period, patent rights are limited to uses under regulatory review for products, methods of using a product, and methods of manufacturing a product. SEC. 6. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to clarify and update various subsections regarding rights and provisions. Section 156 of title 35, United States Code, is amended to clarify and update various subsections regarding rights and provisions, including patent term extensions for American Legion. The design patents for the badges of the American Legion, American Legion Women's Auxiliary, and Sons of the American Legion are renewed and extended for 14 years with all rights and privileges. The design patent for the badge of the Sons of the American Legion, numbered 92,187, is renewed and extended for 14 years with all rights and privileges. SEC. 8. INTERVENING RIGHTS. The renewals and extensions of patents under section 6 will not result in infringement of the patent for any use that began after the patent expired but before the enactment of this Act.
